title: Survive Long Enough to Get Lucky
abstract: Drawing on 20 years of experience in game development—including time as a Game Director of LEGO games and running a successful small studio for a decade—this session offers a unique, veteran perspective on navigating the current challenging landscape of the industry. This talk centres on the crucial philosophy of "Survive Long Enough to Get Lucky", providing attendees with actionable strategies to maintain resilience during tough times, and to successfully create and capitalise on opportunities

speakers.name: Rob Hewson
speakers.bio: CEO & Creative Director Rob Hewson has been a Lead Designer and Game Director at TT Games and other studios, and has worked directly with the likes of Disney, Warner Brothers, Universal, DC Comics, Microsoft, Sega and Konami leading the design of hit games like LEGO Star Wars: The Force Awakens, LEGO Jurassic World, LEGO Batman 3, LEGO The Hobbit, LEGO Legends of Chima, LEGO The Lord of the Rings and Hydrophobia. At Huey Games he has secured major clients including Konami, Devolver, Marvelous Eu

title: Prague Game Accelerator
abstract: oin us for an inspiring session about the very first edition of the Prague Game Accelerator, held from August to November, which created a unique platform to support emerging game studios in the Czech Republic. Over twelve intensive weeks, ten selected teams received hands-on mentorship from leading industry experts, developing their game design, production, marketing, and pitching skills, while gaining access to investors and global networks. In this talk, we will share real outcomes, success stories, key lessons learned, and our plans for the next edition. Discover why the accelerator matters, how it strengthens the game development ecosystem, and why you should be part of it next year.

speakers.name: Michal Roch
speakers.bio: Michal is in the industry for more than 15 years, starting his career in Keen Software House and eventually kickstarting his own studio Honestly Games and launching a successful indie title Lords & Villeins. He spent several years in Swedish incubator Spelkollektivet, met hundreds of indie devs all around the world and currently works with the Czech Gamedev Association, helps organizing the GDS Prague and manages the Prague Gamedev Accelerator.

title: Automated Testing Of Quests In Kingdom Come: Deliverance II
abstract: As quests in Kingdom Come: Deliverance II are not linear and the player has freedom in how to approach them, there are a huge number of combinations that need to be thoroughly tested. That is why we have incorporated automated testing into our processes. In this talk we will go over how we approached automated testing in KCD2, what the process looked like from test creation to iterations during active development, what worked for us and what didn’t, focusing mainly on automation of quest testing

speakers.name: David Bobek
speakers.bio: David Bobek joined Warhorse Studios in 2022 as a QA Tester, where he worked on automated testing and compliance testing of Kingdom Come: Deliverance II.

title: How To Keep Your Project On Course When Plans Fall Apart
abstract: Every game starts with a vision — but the path from concept to launch is never straightforward. Join Jonathan Court, Executive Producer at GRIP Studios, as he shares how to keep a project on course when plans fall apart. Learn how planning becomes a creative tool to adapt, anticipate change, and still deliver something extraordinary. Packed with real examples and hard-earned insights, this talk reveals what it takes to guide teams through chaos to success.

speakers.name: Jonathan Court
speakers.bio: BAFTA-winning producer Jonathan Court is a veteran game development leader with decades of experience delivering award-winning AAA titles across multiple genres and platforms. He has overseen more than 20 releases, including Alien: Isolation, Halo Wars 2, Spartan: Total Warrior, and Hyenas. Jonathan is currently Executive Producer at GRIP Studios, leading an unannounced project.

title: 20 years building game companies. - learnings, anecdotes and what this had to do with being an industrial artist
abstract: In this session, Hendrik Lesser will draw on two decades of shaping the European games industry as the founder and CEO of Remote Control Productions. He will share candid anecdotes and key lessons learned from founding, growing, and supporting a network of development studios across multiple countries.

speakers.name: Hendrik Lesser
speakers.bio: Entrepreneur and founder Hendrik Lesser is the CEO of the international production house remote control productions. After starting out more than 20 years ago in the industry, he has built a global family of independent development studios, which today consists of 15 teams in six countries with more than 400 passionate game makers. Most recently, he founded the politically conscious game publishing label Lesser Evil.

title: Czech Audiovisual Fund and new video games support
abstract: The transformation of the Film Fund into the Audiovisual Fund also brings support for the Czech gaming industry. Detailed information on what opportunities this will bring to Czech game developers in the coming years, how the SFA works, who will be target audience, and what the entire process will look like.

speakers.name: David Šemík
speakers.bio: Game developer, designer, programmer, and artist. He is the co-author of Mafia I and II, the author of the virtual model kit Monzo. For the last ten years, he has been a member of Amanita Design. After this year’s transformation of the Cinematography Fund into the Audiovisual Fund, he is a member of the council for the support animated films and video games.

title: Modding support in Kingdom Come: Deliverance 1 & 2
abstract: For KCD1 and 2, we wanted to give players as much freedom as possible to modify the game. Along the way, we ran into various issues — from releasing our internal tools, to loading the mods themselves, to integrating new data into the game. More problems came after release: using mods with incompatible versions of game, failure to follow recommended practices, corrupted saves, etc. In this talk, I’ll present several specific problems we dealt with — including some we never managed to solve.

speakers.name: Martin Labuť
speakers.bio: Martin Labuť has worked in Warhorse studios for 9 years, on both Kingdom Come: Deliverances. Among other things, he oversaw the release of modding tools for both games.

title: Panel Discussion - Legal Basics for Indies
abstract: Legal stuff isn’t just for the big studios, indies need it from day one. This panel brings together top video game lawyers, consultants, and Czech game veterans to give you clear practical guidance on running your indie studio the smart way. We will cover setting up your business, protecting your IP, licensing, and protecting your brand - all in plain language, no legalese. Expect lots of real-life stories, lessons learnt, and tips you can actually use to stay creative, safe and one step ahead.

speakers.name: Nav Sunner
speakers.bio: Nav Sunner is the founder of a video games legal and business consultancy called ‘Navatron’. Has been involved with the video games industry since early 90’s. Has acted as both in-house counsel and external adviser for a variety of companies in the industry including some of the largest developers, publishers and service companies. Nav also holds advisory and board positions for some video game developers and publishers and gets involved in the acquisitions and IPO's of video games businesses.

title: Funding Opportunities For Video Games Developers In 2026 - The Creative Europe Media Program
abstract: Creative Europe is the European Union‘s programme to support the culture and audiovisual sectors. Its MEDIA strand supports the development of new films, video games, TV productions and online formats, distribution, film festivals and markets, training programmes for audiovisual professionals, cinemas and VOD platforms. What are the funding opportunities available to developers and professionals from gaming industry? What projects are eligible to receive support and under which conditions?

speakers.name: Anna Bartošková
speakers.bio: Anna Bartošková graduated from the Faculty of Arts at Charles University with a major in cultural studies. Before joining the Creative Europe MEDIA Desk, she worked for the Forum of Independents at the Karlovy Vary International Film Festival. She also collaborated with the festival Days of European Films and regularly organized the Prague Quadrennial.

title: Riding The Game Dev Rollercoaster For 10 Years
abstract: These are our stories (and learnings!) from riding up and down the indie game dev rollercoaster for more than a decade. We survived near death situations - almost closed the studio several times - but each time we respawned from the ashes to rise. And then we repeated it again and AGAIN and...

speakers.name: Filip Fischer
speakers.bio: Over more than 20 years, I co-founded and/or led studios like Pixelfederation and Geewa. The last 10 years, I am co-building Charged Monkey, a Czech and Slovak mobile game studio. I also co-founded the Slovak Game Developers Association more than 10 years ago and have been active ever since as board member.

title: Panel Discussion - How to Prepare for Negotiations with a Publisher
abstract: Getting your game developed is one thing, getting it funded and published is another. We will unpack what really goes into a publishing agreement: revenue splits, IP ownership, and who controls what. You will also hear what to prepare before talks begin, when to bring in a lawyer, and get some hard-earned tips from real negotiations. Whether you are pitching your first title or expanding your studio, this practical session will help you walk into publisher meetings ready to play smart.

speakers.name: Nav Sunner
speakers.bio: Nav Sunner is the founder of a video games legal and business consultancy called ‘Navatron’. Has been involved with the video games industry since early 90’s. Has acted as both in-house counsel and external adviser for a variety of companies in the industry including some of the largest developers, publishers and service companies. Nav also holds advisory and board positions for some video game developers and publishers and gets involved in the acquisitions and IPO's of video games businesses.

title: Artificial voices and Avatars
abstract: I’ll present recent progress in creating artificial voices by blending different timbres, along with a brief look at developing life-like avatars.

speakers.name: Josef Vopička
speakers.bio: Josef Vopička is the co-founder of The MAMA AI, SE and Senior Application Developer at MAMA AI. He has 24 years of experience, including 20 years in R&D and management at IBM Research and IBM Watson. He holds a Ph.D. in Electrical Engineering and is a co-inventor of nine U.S. patents and author of several publications in STT and TTS technologies.

title: The 3 Core Principles Of A Successful Educational Program In A Game Studio
abstract: In today’s evolving game industry, impactful learning isn’t just about courses or tutorials—it’s about building an environment where creativity and innovation thrive, both internally and in your player community. Drawing from my journey at BUas and Bohemia Interactive, where I organized game jams and modding boot camps, I’ll share a distilled framework: Accessibility, Engagement, and Sustainability.

speakers.name: Emanuele Ardolino
speakers.bio: Emanuele Ardolino, Producer at Bohemia Interactive currently working on Arma Reforger and Arma 4. With a background in art history and exhibition curation - he moved to the gaming industry aiming to create engaging video game experiences blending art, entertainment and fun.

title: Mafia: The Old Country: Using MetaHuman in a AAA Character Pipeline
abstract: Walkthrough of the Metahuman technology integration for Mafia: The Old Country, behind the scenes of the heads and hair assets creation.

speakers.name: Ivan Čerevko
speakers.bio: Ivan Cerevko is a Principal Character Artist with over 13 years of experience in the game industry. He began his career at Warhorse Studios, where he contributed to the critically acclaimed Kingdom Come: Deliverance and its sequel, Kingdom Come: Deliverance II. In his recent role at Hangar 13, he continues to push artistic and technical boundaries on the game Mafia: The Old Country.

title: Build Your Franchise Vision Early: 10 most common mistakes
abstract: Building a franchise is important if you want a sustainable studio. It is also the potential investors and publishers look for. Is there an ownable and protectable IP? Does it connect emotionally? Will it stand out? Is it protectable? Christian Fonnesbech will share the most common mistakes found from working with many developers and publishers across the world.

speakers.name: Christian Fonnesbech
speakers.bio: Founder and Head of IP Development at Leverage, partnering with games companies to develop lasting franchises and brands. Recent clients include Bandai Namco, Raw Fury and Funcom. Christian focuses on crafting the roots of a project into lasting global properties and brands. With a background spanning 35+ game projects, 100s of consulting projects, and leadership roles at Nordisk Games and Interactive Media Arts, Christian brings practical insights into IPs & franchises.

title: Learnings from 40 years games industry
abstract: I have been making games for over 40 years. A lot of things changed, but many remained the same, so we can all learn from them. So, will walk through some of these key learnings which still apply today and also kill some myths I am hearing again and again just to show you how ridiculous they are from today. At last I try to show you where we are heading from now on in our awesome industry.

speakers.name: Teut Weidemann
speakers.bio: Teut Weidemann is a game producer for nearly 40 years now and works as a freelance consultant for f2p & GaaS since 2007, with clients like Supercell, Ubisoft, Jagex, Rovio, Techland, CD Project among his clients. He ran his own dev studio for 10 years with an exit and was CEO of CDG AG. He worked on over 100 titles on most platforms since 8bit was born. He is a well known & awarded keynote speaker and loves to share his passion for everything games.

title: The Road to Cyberpunk 2077 and Building a Career Beyond the Dream Project
abstract: A behind-the-scenes look at how Csaba started his career and reached the Cyberpunk 2077 development team, what he learned along the way, and why he eventually chose a new direction. It’s not just about the big project. It’s about growth, change, and discovering what truly matters in your career.

speakers.name: Csaba Szilagyi
speakers.bio: Csaba is the Art Director at North Beach Games Prague with 20+ years of experience, specializing in hard-surface modelling. He has contributed to major titles such as Cyberpunk 2077, The Witcher 3, Metal Eden, Crysis 3, Ryse: Son of Rome and many more.

title: Mafia the Old Country | Seamless Cinematics Deep Dive
abstract: Join us for a deep dive into the creation process of seamless transition between gameplay and cinematics, as we developed them in Mafia: The Old Country. Learn how to keep players engaged and make cinematics feel like an integral part of the game world. Explore practical approaches, do's and don'ts, and how to avoid common but costly pitfalls, that will keep your producer happy. From narrative to planning, from design to tech, from mocap to animation, we'll break down how to get rid of the cut!

speakers.name: Theodore Hilhorst
speakers.bio: Senior technical mission designer working on AAA titles, client-based work, and personal projects for over 10 years. Although recently I'm mostly known for my work on Mafia the Old Country doing missions 4 (Il Barone) & 10 (La Festa), building technically complex set pieces and of course the seamles stransitions. During this conference I'll present a talk about Seamless Transitions together with the cinematic artist: Igor Sobolev

speakers.name: Igor Sobolev
speakers.bio: cinematic artist

title: Designing Across Changing Dimensions
abstract: Giving players real-time control to switch between dimensions—each changing how the world looks, behaves, and plays—creates unique design and technical challenges. This talk explores how our team tackled these during the development of Cosmo Tales, sharing key problems, solutions, and insights for keeping constantly shifting game states fun, clear, and cohesive.

speakers.name: Jan Vaněček
speakers.bio: Jan began his career designing board and card games before moving into video games at Geewa, where he designed the mobile RPG Smashing Four. He later joined Keen Software House, leading the live operations of Space Engineers and initiating development on its sequel. Jan now works at Bohemia Interactive, developing a brand-new space adventure titled Cosmo Tales.

title: Panel Discussion - Global Game Publishing Today: Strategies, Risks & How to Succeed
abstract: The panel brings together leading experts from global publishing to discuss the realities of today’s games industry. Vladimír moderates a deep dive into securing a publisher, releasing your game, and what both developers and publishers must know in 2025+. Joining him are directors Anton Ravin (Fulqrum Publishing), Mario Gerhold (ex-Koch Media/Plaion, My.Games), Guillaume Jamet (ex–Plug In Digital), and Tomáš Pšenička (North Beach Games), who will share their perspectives on current challenges.

speakers.name: Vladimír Geršl
speakers.bio: Vladimír Geršl is a game producer, entrepreneur, and CEO of Cyber Sail Consulting. He has nearly 25 years of experience in the games business and has worked long-term with companies such as Activision, Sony, and Plaion. He directly led eight premium titles and helped dozens of studios secure publishing or investment. He runs one of the globally leading consulting agencies in the games industry and is actively involved in industry lobbying in both the Czech Republic and the EU.

title: The Long Game: Evolving from Startup to Sustainable Studio
abstract: In gaming, early success can be brief—sustaining success long-term requires vision, resilience, and constant reinvention. Vlad Ceraldi offers insights from his career and on Offworld’s 10-year journey from startup beginnings to a global studio, sharing valuable lessons on growth, community, leadership, and the business mechanics behind creative independence. Attendees will leave with practical tips to grow responsibly while staying true to their core values.

speakers.name: Vlad Ceraldi
speakers.bio: Vlad is the CEO of Offworld and a gaming executive with over 25 years of experience building and leading companies, studios, and teams to deliver top-performing games across various platforms. He has held diverse roles throughout his career, including Lead Programmer, Technical Director, Producer, Executive Producer, SVP of Studios, and CEO.

title: Panel Discussion - Deals That Define the Game: Inside the World of Gaming Transactions
abstract: From billion-dollar acquisitions to strategic investments, M&A is reshaping the gaming landscape. But are these deals a launchpad to global success or a shortcut to losing creative control? This session brings together top experts who have been behind some of the most influential gaming transactions, including deals involving Embracer Group, Geewa, Warhorse or Tripledot Studios. If you are a rising studio eyeing growth or an investor scouting the next breakout hit, this is must-attend session.

speakers.name: Michał Pękała
speakers.bio: An advocate, a partner and head of the Video Games & Entertainment practice of Rymarz Zdort Maruta. Has extensive experience in advising entities from the video game industry such as developers, publishers, industry investors, asset providers, freelancers, and influencers, as well as e-sports teams. Also advises on financing transactions for gaming entities and is a legal expert for WIPO (World Intellectual Property Organisation) in relation to video games.

title: The Hidden Complexity of Branched Dialogues in Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2
abstract: A look into the process of creating branching dialogues in Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2. What makes them feel realistic, how players can influence what NPCs (don’t) tell them, where unexpected complications arise, what to avoid, and what remains hidden from the players.

speakers.name: Martina Daněk
speakers.bio: Narrative Designer at Warhorse Studios, Voice-Over Director, and Editor. I joined Warhorse in 2020 as a Junior Quest Designer on a secret, codenamed project that was released this year under the title Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2. During my time on the game, I helped craft immersive stories for various quests, wrote dialogue, and oversaw some of the romantic plotlines. Later in development, I also directed the English voice-overs.

title: Kromlech: Between Sword and Myth – How to Build Fantasy That Respects History
abstract: Fantasy often borrows from history, but rarely understands it. Kromlech draws from the material culture of La Tène Europe — from real weapons, garments, and architecture — and reshapes it into a world of sword & sorcery. This talk explores how historical accuracy can strengthen both authenticity and atmosphere in a fictional world, and why history should be treated not as a backdrop, but as a tool for world-building identity. In short, how to design a world where magic and ritual feel believable

speakers.name: Milan Hrycjuk
speakers.bio: Milan Hrycjuk is a game designer at Perun Creative, currently working on the roguelite action RPG Kromlech. With a background in film directing and UX/UI design, he approaches games as a dialogue between story, space, and player intent. Years of LARP design and Celtic La Tène reenactment shape his view of authenticity and myth as two sides of the same creative process.

title: Music System Case Study - The Many Faces of FMOD
abstract: On this rather short talk, I'll try to show you how I use the internal logic of FMOD middleware to deliver a specific music system functionality through two different approaches. An event structure can look different and have different means of control while still achieving the same goal. In short, I will showcase FMOD's visual verstaility and adaptability to one's personal preferences. We will compare the capabilities of parameter sheet timeline versus the event timeline, in mere 25 minutes.

speakers.name: David Wurczel
speakers.bio: Don't really enjoy writing about myself! Gonna make it short. I'm a gamer, music composer, classical guitarist, sound designer and technical audio designer in games. If you played KCD:2 or Volcanoids, you might have already heard some of my work. I spend most of my time at Warhorse Studios but I'm also writing music for Crimson Capes (Poor Locke), last year's GDS Best Pitch winners and a few other smaller game titles like Magna Regna or Knightcraft.

title: Old narrative tropes unexplored even today
abstract: Ways of narration: Old narrative tropes unexplored even today. Players love things that are familiar yet somehow unknown. But have you asked yourself: What is the unknown to the modern world? During the talk, you will learn multiple tropes in narration that intrigued us were called innovative yet we don't see them present in most of the games. This tool might give you leverage to check if your game has something unique to offer or create new ideas based on the presented thinking patterns. The partner of the talk is the Creative Europe MEDIA Desk CZ.

speakers.name: Radosław Klasa
speakers.bio: I have worked both in small indie companies and AAA companies since 2017. Co-creator of the Gamedevowe Pogaduchy initiative, which integrates the Polish community. Advisory Board member for Game Industry Conference (GIC). Always keen to promote the game dev industry to new generations and help the broken, the beaten and the damned. Passionate about exploring new and original mechanics that enhance game narration and aesthetics.

title: Kingdom Come: Deliverance II – Chasing 60 FPS In An Open-world RPG
abstract: This talk shares lessons learned from optimizing Kingdom Come: Deliverance II to meet its performance targets. We will look at how we profile and measure performance in a large open-world game, the pitfalls we hit when trying to understand how the game actually runs, and the approaches that proved most useful. The second half of the session walks through a mix of optimization tips and techniques that proved effective for us in practice.

speakers.name: Martin Matouš
speakers.bio: Martin Matouš is a programmer at Warhorse Studios with seven years of gamedev experience. He initially worked on core gameplay systems, contributing to features such as the dialogue and quest systems, and later focused on engine improvements, optimization, and overall game performance.

title: Panel Discussion - Power-Up for Developers: Financing Games Through the New Czech Video Game Incentives Scheme
abstract: The Czech Republic has introduced a new incentive scheme for video game development under the Czech Audiovisual Fund. This panel will unpack how the program works, who will it benefit, and its potential impact on the Czech gaming ecosystem. Join leading experts as we explore eligibility, timeframe, positive and critical voices on the scheme and whether this initiative can truly level up the Czech gaming industry.

speakers.name: Pavel Barák
speakers.bio: Pavel has been active in the game industry for more than 20 years. A co-founder and chairman of the Czech Game Developers Association (GDACZ). For the past ten years, he has been the director of the oldest independent game development conference in Europe, the Game Developers Session, which is also one of the largest game conferences in the region. In 2005, he founded Handjoy, a game development studio that specializes in mobile and advertising games and has released more than 10 titles.

title: Panel Discussion - Clone Wars
abstract: Where does homage end and cloning begin? Join industry experts as they unpack the hottest controversies in look-alike games, reveal how far inspiration can legally go, and spotlight the creative and business risks every studio should watch for. A sharp, energetic session for anyone in an industry where originality is both a challenge and an opportunity.

speakers.name: Kostyantyn Lobov
speakers.bio: Kostya is a partner and co-head of the interactive entertainment practice at Harbottle & Lewis. He works extensively with clients in the video game and esports sectors, including studios and publishers of all sizes. His client base also includes brand owners, production companies and tech startups. They range in size from SMEs to multinational corporations. Kostya is recognised as a leading lawyer in The Legal 500, IP Stars and Chambers and Partners.

title: Panel Discussion - Safe Mode Activated: AI in Games Without Breaking the Rules
abstract: AI is transforming the way games are developed. But as AI becomes integral to creative pipelines, it also raises tough legal and ethical questions. We’ll explore how studios are integrating AI into their daily workflows, not only to accelerate production but to build practical governance approaches that support responsible use. Expect a clear, practical look at IP risks, emerging regulatory expectations, and the concrete steps developers can take to stay compliant without slowing innovation.

speakers.name: Nick Allan
speakers.bio: Nick is a video games lawyer and a partner at Mishcon de Reya in London. Nick’s practice focuses on the $200 billion global video games industry, including PC, console, mobile, web-browser and VR/AR games. Has been recognised by Chambers and Partners and the Legal 500 as a leading practitioner in respect of video games. Nick specialises in contract negotiations, including development, publishing and licensing deals, as well as advice in respect of intellectual property and regulatory matters.

title: Panel Discussion - Get Funded! How to benefit from national funding in other EU countries?
abstract: How can you benefit from national public and private funding opportunities in other EU countries? In this panel, EGDF board members will discuss the funding instruments available in their countries and how you can benefit from them.

speakers.name: Jari-Pekka Kaleva
speakers.bio: Jari-Pekka Kaleva is an institution nerd helping the game industry geeks to revolutionise the world we live in. At the moment, he works as Managing Director at the European game industry umbrella organisation EGDF and as Chief Policy Advisor at Neogames Finland association. He has more than a decade of experience tracking both national and EU level political decision making from the game industry’s point of view.

title: Sources of narrative craft from industry's best
abstract: This report is reflection of personal experience and over 40 interviews with top narrative experts of the industry conducted as part of the bigger project. We will discuss what hints and tips are used by many interviewed Narrative designers, what software is their favorite and why, what books do they advice to use and what do they advice to colleagues the industry. Together we will discuss insights and learn from industry veterans.

speakers.name: Yaraslau Kot
speakers.bio: Game designer and narrative designer since 1996. Is PhD, LLM, MPsych. Works in Bajka Games studio and at A little Bit Different Studio, Research Fellow at European Humanities University. He worked on many tabletop, larp and video games. Among them such titles as: Eastern Frontier: 1581; It Lurks Below; RhyDin; Lands of Evermore; Vampires the Masquerade: St. Louis by Night Online; Chernobylite 1-2; Proze; Replaced; Raccoon Mania; Green City Harvest, etc. Author of books and articles.

title: Panel Discussion - How To Grow And Develop Sustainable Game Industry Clusters
abstract: GAME-ER is a 36-month research project funded by HORIZON Europe and UKRI, dedicated to understanding the unique dynamics of local and regional video game clusters. We aim to provide policymakers and decision-makers with the knowledge and tools needed to foster thriving video game clusters.

speakers.name: Michal Roch
speakers.bio: Michal is in the industry for more than 15 years, starting his career in Keen Software House and eventually kickstarting his own studio Honestly Games and launching a successful indie title Lords & Villeins. He spent several years in Swedish incubator Spelkollektivet, met hundreds of indie devs all around the world and currently works with the Czech Gamedev Association, helps organizing the GDS Prague and manages the Prague Gamedev Accelerator.

title: Gamebadges - Educator Stakeholder Meeting
abstract: Gamebadges – a European-wide, competence-based badge ecosystem designed to align education with industry demands – has reached its piloting phase! We are happy to invite any game develpment educators to this meeting to find out more about how this project can improve their teaching and help their students on their journey.

speakers.name: David Šosvald
speakers.bio: David Šosvald graduated from Charles University in 2023 with a degree in Visual Computing and Game Development. Now pursuing a PhD, he focuses his research on the impact of adaptive game elements on players' attitudes in video games. He also takes part in the Gamebadges project, developing a badge ecosystem for the European game industry. He's a proud organiser of the GDS game jam.

title: Lean Production - what can we learn from others
abstract: How come game budgets increased so much even though we have experience and tools to develop games more efficiently? The book The Toyota Way introduced the philosophy of Lean Production and in this talk we will challenge ourselves about how to think differently and learn from others in order to produce games faster and better.

speakers.name: Tobias Sjögren
speakers.bio: Tobias started as a games programmer in 1996 and has since been based in Stockholm, Sweden. He was studio head of DICE Stockholm where Battlefield 1942 was produced. Since then he held management and business development roles at companies line DDM, Paradox, White Wolf Entertainment and Starbreeze.

title: Going from indie hell to AA chaos
abstract: What happens when a small indie team suddenly decides to “level up”? This talk dives into our journey from a 4-person indie studio to nearly 30 developers, switching from Unity to Unreal, and from pure creative freedom to full-blown production chaos. I’ll share what worked, what didn’t, and what we wish we knew before taking the leap from indie to AA development.

speakers.name: Jiří Vašica
speakers.bio: Jiří Vašica is co-founder and CEO of Perun Creative. Worked as the producer and lead programmer of the award-winning game Hobo: Tough Life. Currently is working on the upcoming next-gen game Kromlech.

title: How to create your masterpiece
abstract: How to come up with an idea for an exceptional work, how to cultivate it, push it through, execute it, and bring it to completion.

speakers.name: Daniel Vávra
speakers.bio: Daniel Vávra is a Czech video game writer, director, designer and co-founder of Warhorse Studios. He is best known as the lead writer of the video games Mafia (2002), Mafia II (2010) and Kingdom Come: Deliverance (2018) and upcoming Kingdom Come 2.

title: Fireside Chat
abstract: Fireside Chat

speakers.name: Anselm Pyta
speakers.bio: Anselm Pyta co-founded the German animation and games studio “Studio Seufz.” He is the creator of the idle-adventure hybrid “The Longing” (2020), where he was responsible for artwork, writing, game design, and sound. He started out by making viral web games like “Lucky Tower” (2010) or “Murder” (2014). Currently, he is working on “Lucky Tower Ultimate,” a humorous roguelike set to be released from Early Access in 2026. His next project will be a spiritual sequel to The Longing.

title: Designing Brave
abstract: Game design as an art form: a space where personal vision meets public reception. Reflection on creative risks, design integrity, and the ongoing search for balance between authenticity and accessibility in modern game development.

speakers.name: Viktor Bocan
speakers.bio: Game designer and writer for more than 30 years; worked on small and big games, lead designer of the original Operation Flashpoint, design lead and design director for Kingdom Come: Deliverance I & II. Gaming enthusiast & seeker of purity in game design.

title: Jagged Alliance 3 Narrative: Designing Characters People Actually Remember
abstract: This talk is a post-mortem of the narrative work on Jagged Alliance 3, focusing on how to create memorable characters and make players actually care about their decisions. It covers the challenges of building a sequel to a beloved franchise – expanding its world with more content, deepening its decision branches and consequences, and still staying true to the original’s tone. The session also includes practical advice on narrative design documentation and writing workflows.

speakers.name: Radomir Mirchev
speakers.bio: Radomir Mirchev is the narrative designer behind Jagged Alliance 3, responsible for the game’s worldbuilding, story, NPC, and most of its quest content. He has worked on multiple indie projects, including Surviving Mars at Haemimont Games. Designer of the long-running Stalker Bulgaria live-action series (2009–2022). Creator of Bulgaria’s first Kickstarter-funded board game and publisher of two successful KS titles.

title: Design For Everything In Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2
abstract: We will explore the relation of design and iteration on the example of NPC sight in Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2. How we made NPCs see in a realistic, open world RPG, what we thought is going to work and what we actually had to do. What it takes to tune a system to behave in both scripted and emergent situations, to provide enjoyable but nontrivial gameplay and enhance immersion. We will be reminded of lessons that might seem basic but still could pose a challenge over 10+ years of development.

speakers.name: Vadim Petrov
speakers.bio: Vadim Petrov is a game developer specializing in AI and audio programming, with a passion for creating responsive, immersive systems. From designing intelligent NPCs to implementing adaptive music and real-time sound behaviors, Vadim loves to create environments that draw the audience in. In his free time he develops custom software tools for live musical performance — crafting interactive environments and reactive visuals that respond to musicians in real time.

title: Mafia: The Old Country: World & Biomes
abstract: In this session, Hangar 13 showcases how they created early 20th century Sicily nature through detailed landscapes and biomes in Mafia: The Old Country. We will go through how the creation of the world proceeded through project lifetime. What were the major steps in videogame development from pre-production to finalization phases. Everything is accompanied by example references, images and graphs to help us understand the processes and challenges.

speakers.name: Dominik Regec
speakers.bio: As the Lead Environment Artist at Hangar 13, I am passionate about creating immersive and realistic environments, notably for the acclaimed MAFIA franchise. I have 15+ years of professional practice in 3D graphics, realtime rendering and game development, including 5 years of work experience in the USA. During my career I went through various art & tech-art disciplines: creation of props, vehicles, buildings, production of game city districts, mission set-pieces and even whole game worlds.

title: Business Crash Course
abstract: Based on my lectures given in the Prague Game Accelerator and my 21 year of experience in running companies. I will tell you how to set up a company if that's really needed. We will look on how to spot good and bad people to do business with, how to avoid many pitfalls of doing bad decisions early and how to keep costs low and profits high. If you plan to start a studio or you are fresh to the scene, this talk will save you from a lot of suffering. All based on my actual experience.

speakers.name: Martin Boháč
speakers.bio: Martin founder Allodium in 2007 and led development of two big online MMO browser-based games and later Fantasy Sports game which led to Allodium becoming a major supplier of online scratchcards for national lotteries. Martin also founder GameDevHub, an online school for game professionals. Lately Martin launched a new studio called Ionic Games, which is developing a hex-based strategy game Cyberpolis.

title: Leveraging AI And LLMs To Transform Collaboration In Teams
abstract: Discover how AI and Large Language Models can transform collaboration and communication in game development teams. This talk explores practical workflows.

speakers.name: Diego Ricchiuti
speakers.bio: 16 years of experience in the game industry, Diego worked in AAA and AA, he is also a published author by CRC press with a book on game design (Game Design Tools) and one about game publishing (The game business guide book). He works for various studios and publishers as creative director and consultant.

title: Bringing Characters to Life in Kingdom Come: Deliverance II
abstract: Creating characters for Kingdom Come: Deliverance II meant finding the balance between historical authenticity, artistic expression, and technical limitations. This talk offers a glimpse into how character artists bring the medieval world to life —from refining the faces, crafting diverse outfits to tackling the challenges of the game’s intricate clothing system with so many, many layers... and yes, there will be also some animals.

speakers.name: Anna Pačesová
speakers.bio: Anna Pačesová is the Lead Character Artist at Warhorse Studios. She started in QA 11 years ago before moving to the 3D environment team, where she spent six years creating assets and landscapes for KCD I and II. She later joined the character art team and was soon offered the opportunity to lead it, shaping the visual identity of the series together.

title: Thread Lightly: Parallelizing Gameplay and Tools with the Job System
abstract: Learn how to leverage Unity’s Job System outside ECS, from Editor baking to runtime logic. This talk explores how to integrate parallelism into your existing workflows without adopting the full DOTS stack. We’ll look at practical examples like baking static data and iterating through it, showing how Jobs can speed up editor-time, build-time and runtime operations while keeping your project structure clean, modular, and scalable.

speakers.name: Arnaud Briche
speakers.bio: Senior Partner Engineer at Unity, empowering developers to maximize engine potential through technical guidance and optimization strategies. Previously Senior Gameplay Engineer at Ubisoft developing core parkour mechanics and VR interactions for the award-winning Assassin's Creed Nexus VR (Meta Quest Game of the Year 2023). Active gamejam mentor and performance optimization enthusiast, bridging technical excellence with community growth across C# and C++ development.

title: Casting Actors
abstract: Asking an actor to audition for your game is a complex process; even more so for the actor if they’re given a less than ideal audition brief. Lack of context, information, and instruction can turn what could be a great performance into an MP3 destined for the desktop trash. In “Casting Actors” you’ll see the breakdown process and then a live-audition by an actor leading all the way up to delivery from the actor’s perspective.

speakers.name: Mike Bodie
speakers.bio: Mike is an Olivier-Award nominated, and 5 x One Voice Award-winning classically trained Actor/VO, VO Director, Performance Capture artist based in London and Los Angeles. He has over +150 game titles as a VO, and is one of the founders and performers in the Olivier and Tony award-winning theatre company Mischief Theatre. Some of his previous AAA VO work in games includes WOLFENSTEIN 2, STAR WARS: BATTLEFRONT 2, THE DIVISION 2, CONTROL, GHOST RECON: BREAKPOINT, STAR CITIZEN, SEA OF THIEVES

title: Well-Being and Working in Games: What Makes You Happy Can Also Make You Sick
abstract: The media industries generally, and games in particular, thrive on the passion, but that passion often comes at a cost. Behind the glamour of working in the media lies a growing crisis—one of burnout, anxiety, abuse, and exhaustion. Why do so many professionals report feeling both deeply fulfilled and profoundly unwell? How did we get this far, and what can be done? Mark Deuze maps the systemic issues that make creative work both exhilarating and unsustainable, and offers a way out.

speakers.name: Mark Deuze
speakers.bio: Mark Deuze is Professor of Media Studies at the University of Amsterdam, The Netherlands. Awards include a Fulbright scholarship at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles (US), a Research Fellowship at Leeds University (UK), and several honorary appointments at universities in the UK, Australia, Portugal, Germany, and Russia. Publications of his work include 14 books, most recently “Well-Being and Creative Careers: What Makes You Happy Can Also Make You Sick” (Intellect, 2025).

title: We Grew Up in War: Designing a Different Kind of War Game
abstract: Drawing on a decade of making games about war and history, this talk shares practical methods for treating heavy themes in indie production. Lukáš will unpack Charles Games’ design pillars, show how they shape We Grew Up in War, and discuss working with historians and communities to turn lived wartime experience into playable moments.

speakers.name: Lukáš Kolek
speakers.bio: Lukáš Kolek is the co-founder and CEO of Charles Games, the studio behind 10+ indie titles including the award-winning Playing Kafka, Svoboda 1945: Liberation and Beecarbonize, enjoyed by hundreds of thousands of players worldwide. Charles Games creates experiences that tackle serious themes, from historical trauma to the climate crisis.

title: CPU Architecture Internals: x86, ARM, and Performance Basics
abstract: A grounded overview of how modern CPUs (x86-64 and ARM64) execute code. Introduces pipelines, caches, branch prediction, SIMD, and hybrid P/E-cores, with practical examples from game and engine code such as data layout, branch-less logic, multi-threading, and cross-architecture pitfalls.

speakers.name: Martin Pernica
speakers.bio: CTO by day, developer by night. He has been working in the game industry for quite some time and has a passion for anything technology related that helps his teams make their dreams come true.

title: From the Fuckup Files
abstract: „From the Fuckup Files” is a fast, honest look at the key lessons from 25 years in game development. The talk covers three themes: allocating and growing talent, what makes a strong co-dev partner, and how the industry has changed. No sugarcoating—just practical insights shaped by real mistakes and the progress they created.

speakers.name: Tom Roller
speakers.bio: Tom Roller is the CEO of Plan A and a 25-year veteran of game development and co-dev production (Battlefield 6, Dragon's Dogma 2, MS Flight Simulator). He specializes in building high-performance teams, scaling talent, and shaping partnerships with top AA/AAA studios. His leadership style is direct, practical, and rooted in one belief: growth comes from mistakes - if you know how to turn them into progress.

title: 10 Useful Tips for Porting Your Game
abstract: Making your game multi-platform by porting to consoles and online storefronts is a great way to reach a wider audience. Without proper preparation, however, the process can quickly become expensive, confusing, and time-consuming. Tomáš shares practical advice for a smoother porting journey, from engineering insights like managing crossplay, to production tips that help your team navigate platform requirements with confidence.

speakers.name: Tomáš Hoffman
speakers.bio: With more than six years in game development, Tomáš has built his career around solving complex technical challenges in simulation games. On his last project, Firefighting Simulator: Ignite, he led the porting to PS5 and Xbox Series X/S and now works as a Technical Producer at Grip Studios on an upcoming, unannounced title.

title: Mechanics As Meaning
abstract: This talk will explore procedural rhetoric, a concept described by Ian Bogost as the way in which game mechanics communicate meaning and arguments. Drawing on my Master's thesis on metaphors of growth in game design, I will present practical examples from games to demonstrate how we, as creators, can engage with procedural rhetoric. We will then discuss how procedural rhetorics can be analysed, demonstrating how mechanics can symbolise and convey meaning beyond explicit narrative.

speakers.name: Matěj Hložánek
speakers.bio: I am a co-founder of Herdek, which develops the game Prší (prshee) – a game that won awards at Games for Change in New York and the Aware Games at Blon, and was nominated for the Digital Moment Award at A MAZE Berlin. I studied game design at FAMU in Prague and focus on creating small, meaningful games with a socially critical dimension. I am particularly interested in what game mechanics can symbolize and how to work with metaphors in game design.

title: Gamedev Studios Are Businesses - Treat Them Accordingly
abstract: Publishers and investors focus on three pillars when investing in a game studio: 1) game experience, 2) financial health, and 3) internal processes for growth. Studios handle the first, we handle the rest. Our talk covers the two often-overlooked pillars crucial for investors, publishers, and EU grants application validators. With experience in consulting and banking, we help studios prepare for investor talks, EU grants, and sustainable business development.

speakers.name: Filip Ondras
speakers.bio: I’m Filip Ondras, a finance and process expert based in Vienna. With experience from KPMG and Erste Group, I help creative teams and game studios turn great ideas into profitable businesses. My background in consulting and banking taught me how to bring clarity to complexity, building financial systems, investor strategies, and workflows that fuel growth without killing creativity.

title: Behind-the-Scenes – Factory Faction in Heroes of Might & Magic III
abstract: Horn of the Abyss (HotA) is a meticulously crafted fan-made expansion for Heroes of Might and Magic III, designed to seamlessly integrate with the original game's mechanics and aesthetics. The talk aims to unveil behind-the-scenes stories from the development process of the long-awaited Factory faction, inspired by steampunk & blending together technology and nature. The talk covers multiple topics – ranging from art and design, music and sound, to single and multiplayer content.

speakers.name: Alex Tarren
speakers.bio: Alex T. is a developer at HotA Crew, deeply passionate about the HoMM series and its legacy. He joined the team a few years ago, contributing to a project with nearly two decades of history. Throughout the period, HotA Crew has consistently delivered updates and enhancements to their beloved game, preserving its essence while expanding its horizons.

title: Interactive Spatial Audio in Games. How it conveys emotion and impacts perception
abstract: What makes spatial audio immersive isn’t just how it sounds, but how it responds. In this session, Markus Zaunschirm and Clemens Amon from atmoky explore the real-time nature of interactive spatial audio and how it fuels immersion, engagement, and presence in games. They connect psychoacoustic concepts like transportation and plausibility with practical game engine and middleware implementation. The talk will include live demos and a behind-the-scenes look at atmoky’s upcoming acoustics engine.

speakers.name: Clemens Amon
speakers.bio: Clemens Amon, MSc, is Co-Founder and Head of Growth at atmoky, driving adoption of next-generation spatial audio tooling for games and XR. With a Master’s in Electrical and Audio Engineering focused on digital signal processing, he combines technical depth with strategic insight into the immersive audio market. Before atmoky, he spent eight years in applied audio research. His work focuses on how interactive spatial audio and 3D acoustics shapes emotion, perception, and presence.

title: The Essentials of Procedural Game Audio
abstract: You can sculpt sounds at the sample level! This session explores how designing custom synthesizers introduces creative constraints that foster originality. We’ll cover the principles of coding audio generators and demonstrate how they can respond directly to gameplay parameters—such as player speed, item state, or environmental cues. The underlying logic can be integrated into middleware like Wwise or FMOD, ensuring your game’s audio remains distinctive, cohesive, and highly scalable.

speakers.name: Adam Sporka
speakers.bio: Adam Sporka is a game audio researcher, developer, and educator, specializing in interactive music and sound. He composed for Kingdom Come: Deliverance I & II, served as KCD II’s technical music director, and created the Sequence Music Engine which handled the music in the games. He is a principal engineer at Embody, a spatial audio technology start-up. Adam also teaches game audio at University of California, Santa Cruz and holds a Ph.D. in HCI. You can reach him at Twitter @adam_sporka.

title: Sail.Game: How to Find the Right Publisher in the Vast Sea of the Gaming Industry
abstract: Cyber Sail Consulting focuses on connecting developers with publishers. Gaming veteran Mikoláš Tuček will share his tips, insights on the current market situation, and introduce the brand-new matchmaking platform Sail.Game.

speakers.name: Mikoláš Tuček
speakers.bio: Industry veteran whose gaming career officially spans two millennia (well... he started in 1999). He has been the editor-in-chief of SCORE magazine, the host of the Re-Play TV show, and he currently runs the pop-culture podcast Poslední podcast. One of the true gaming evangelists, he has joined Cyber Sail Consulting and is now helping developers find the right publishers. Get in touch if you are Developer struggling to find Publisher, or Publisher/Investor looking for new addition to portfolio!

title: Between the Sign and the Referent: The Semiotics of Videogames
abstract: This presentation explores the semiotics of reality representation in videogames. Semiotics, the study of how meaning is created through signs, provides a compelling framework for understanding how game worlds are constructed and how players interpret them. The talk examines how different types of signs shape not only the representation of reality in videogames, but also the cognitive processes that allow players to perceive a game as an aesthetic and interactive object.

speakers.name: Anton Romanenko
speakers.bio: Anton Romanenko is a game designer at SCS Software and a Ph.D. student at Charles University. He has contributed to several projects, including work as a researcher on American Truck Simulator: Nebraska and as a UX and gameplay designer on American Truck Simulator: DLC Road Trip. His academic and design work both focus on how players interpret meaning in interactive worlds, with a particular interest in multilingual literature and narrative structures in video games.

title: Unforseen Consequences - The Caveats of Planning and How to React to the Unplanned
abstract: Talk about planning for release, finishing and polishing, and about the fact that anything that can go wrong will go wrong. But that doesn't mean it has to stay that way. There is just one question remaining: How to approach this? Small post mortem by the tools developer and kind of "man Friday" about the last two years of development of the Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 and the difficulties we faced and how we overcame them.

speakers.name: Ondrej Sakači
speakers.bio: Technical artist working for Warhorse Studios with broad scope of skills but mainly focused on Enviromental Art. Finished Software Engineering at CTU in Prague and tried a bit of Graphics Programming and UX/UI studies. Helped primarily prior to /and with the release of Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2.

title: Demystifying Marketing: The Art Of Making Your Games Seen And Bought
abstract: Many indies, when faced with the necessity of marketing their games, are often intimidated by the mysticism surrounding it. What do we even do? A typical first thought is to start a social media account, post about your game and maybe go viral, or contact a few influencers and hope for the best. But the reality is simpler than you might think. In this talk, we will remove this mystical veneer and discuss marketing for what it really is: a lot of research, good planning, a strong identity, and a lot of hard work.

speakers.name: Michal Roch
speakers.bio: Michal is in the industry for more than 15 years, starting his career in Keen Software House and eventually kickstarting his own studio Honestly Games and launching a successful indie title Lords & Villeins. He spent several years in Swedish incubator Spelkollektivet, met hundreds of indie devs all around the world and currently works with the Czech Gamedev Association, helps organizing the GDS Prague and manages the Prague Gamedev Accelerator.

title: Game Trailers 101: How to Hook Players and Publishers Alike
abstract: A deep dive into what makes a game trailer truly work - and what makes it fail. We’ll explore the anatomy of a good trailer, the storytelling power of music, and the common mistakes that ruin first impressions. Beyond just editing and pacing, we’ll discuss why trailers matter, how to strategically use different types of trailers throughout your marketing campaign, and how the right trailer can attract not only players but also investors and publishers alike.

speakers.name: Tomas Oliva
speakers.bio: Co-founder at 4Boars, an acclaimed collective of trailer and advertising industry professionals. Recognized for successful advertising campaigns for Assassin's Creed Shadows, Starfield, Star Wars: Andor, Jurassic World: Dominion, Tekken, and numerous other high-profile projects.

title: Cutting Through Creatively In Gaming Campaigns - Kingdom Come: Deliverance Ii
abstract: If you don’t have insanely large media budget, your trailers, reveals and other key campaign assets need to be something very special. An honest peak behind the curtain of the creation of hero assets for the advertising campaign of Kingdom Come: Deliverance II.

speakers.name: Vítek Mičke
speakers.bio: Vítek Mičke is part of the global brand team behind the Kingdom Come: Deliverance II advertising campaign, serving as the lead writer and director of hero assets and commercials - Trailers, Game Reveals, Showcases, Live Action and more.

title: Don't Push The Narrative - Improvise!
abstract: One of the beautiful things about game narratives is their ability to give the player choices. But very often, the choices we're presented with can be trivial, pointless, obvious, or just leaving you questioning why they're there at all. In this talk, we will explore a new frame of mind for designing choices in game narratives – inspired by the art of improv (improvised theatre), with interesting and varied examples from projects we've worked on and ones we haven't, and some we'll improvise!

speakers.name: Alec Shea
speakers.bio: One of the beautiful things about game narratives is their ability to give the player choices. But very often, the choices we're presented with can be trivial, pointless, obvious, or just leaving you questioning why they're there at all. In this talk, we will explore a new frame of mind for designing choices in game narratives – inspired by the art of improv (improvised theatre), with interesting and varied examples from projects we've worked on and ones we haven't, and some we'll improvise!

title: Evolving Passion Projects Into A Business
abstract: Patrik will share his journey of evolving his passion project into a business with thousands of users world wide. Sim Companies, an online business simulation game, boasts over 25,000 daily active users and 4.8/5 rating with millions of downloads across mobile platforms. Do you want to know which challenges the project faced, and how we overcome them? Which marketing approaches worked, and which didn't? How to use data-centric approach to set up your project for success?

speakers.name: Patrik Beck
speakers.bio: Patrik started his career as a C/C++ engineer in the finance industry in the UK and New York. Shortly after moving to Prague, he started working on a browser-based game hobby project, which eventually led to the founding of the multiplayer business simulation strategy game, Sim Companies.

title: The Quest for Blind-Inclusive Game Design
abstract: In this talk, I share my unexpected journey during the development of 1428: Shadows over Silesia, where I coincidentally found myself diving deep into accessibility for blind players despite having no grand ambitions or extensive experience. Join me to uncover the lessons learned from this endeavor and explore whether your indie or AAA game can be made accessible to blind players and whether it’s worth doing.

speakers.name: Petr Kubíček
speakers.bio: Self-taught game designer and programmer with several years of experience. Creator of the medieval action adventure game 1428: Shadows over Silesia.. Currently, besides his own projects, he also works at Bohemia Interactive. Some of the games Petr worked on: Crime Boss: Rockay City, Arma 4, Vigor, 1428: Shadows over Silesia, Kubikon 3D

title: The Effective Hiring At Monster Couch And Why It Works
abstract: The first step of recruitment is the decision not to hire at all. If you, however, decide on recruitment, come and listen to how an indie studio can do it while staying focused on great people and keeping its retention high. In this talk, it will be shown how the book "The Effective Hiring Manager" is put into practice in Monster Couch, with strong emphasis on the team manager's role in the recruitment process.

speakers.name: Michal Karzynski
speakers.bio: Operations Manager in the Polish studio Monster Couch. With years of experience in developing the Pyrkon Fan Festival and building up other organisations, I am currently focusing on all operational procedures and employee growth in Monster Couch.

title: GDS Prague Pitching Session
abstract: The best and bravest of GDS Prague Indie Expo will present their pitch decks in lightning rounds of presentations, followed by questions and discussions with a professional jury. All to compete for a prime spot of the most appreciated pitch of GDS Prague 2025!

speakers.name: Vladimír Geršl
speakers.bio: Vladimír Geršl is a game producer, entrepreneur, and CEO of Cyber Sail Consulting. He has nearly 25 years of experience in the games business and has worked long-term with companies such as Activision, Sony, and Plaion. He directly led eight premium titles and helped dozens of studios secure publishing or investment. He runs one of the globally leading consulting agencies in the games industry and is actively involved in industry lobbying in both the Czech Republic and the EU.

title: Sticks, Ropes and high hopes - Intro
abstract: Together with GDA CZ, Fuchs+Dachs game dev studio is organising a small one day EVENT that would be a part of this year’s Game Developers Session Conference, in Prague. We have one whole day specially organised for small teams, students and young game dev enthusiasts that we would like to greatly benefit from GDS 2025. The event is aimed for anyone interested in working in small teams, studying game design or small indie game dev teams and studios. The first part will be about the upcoming game MAW.

speakers.name: Miroslav Prokop
speakers.bio: Hi, I'm Míra, but usually I go by the nickname Zakroutil. I'm an indie developer from Czechia, I study game design at FAMU and I'm also helping out with some secret stuff over at Fuchs+Dachs Games... And I'm developing my own noir adventure called "MAW" as well.

title: Bell Hat Games and games for children with ADHD
abstract: I will talk about my indie game development experiences and developing a game for children

speakers.name: Matěj Hes
speakers.bio: Matěj Hes is the creative director of Bell Hat Games and a student of Game design at FAMU

title: Regarding Sasha and Student Games Festival
abstract: Our game Regarding Sasha got nominated for Student Game Awards in Warsaw and we would like to talk about our experience at the event.

speakers.name: Michaela Jílková
speakers.bio: I'm a student and I'm currently studying Game Art in SŠUD.

title: The creation of Mařena
abstract: Mařena is an absurd dungeon crawler about a perpetually drunk heroine who is a bit out of control in her life – and yet she keeps going. The game was created out of pure joy of creation and friendship: we met at a gamejam, sat down with a human and creative approach, and our joint project spontaneously grew out of that. The lecture is about everything that went into the creation of our first long-term project.

speakers.name: Daniel Mrázik
speakers.bio: Daniel Mrázik is a student in the Design and Digital Technologies studio at UMPRUM. In his work, he focuses mainly on graphics for video games, illustration, and animation, with a specialization in character design. As a guy from central Slovakia - a region full of castles and chateaus, he is fascinated by the connection between folk symbols, cryptids, and medieval mystique with game art, which is fully reflected in his latest project, Mařena.

title: Sticks, Ropes & Impostor Syndrome
abstract: As a part of the "Sticks, Ropes & High Hopes" event at GDS, I would like to look back at my very chaotic game dev journey and the times when facing my self-doubts has led to some of the most important events of my life. This is going to be a short and informal (and hopefully inspirational) talk, no prerequisites required!

speakers.name: Vojta Siman
speakers.bio: Level designer, music composer and sound designer. I worked on BLACKHOLE by FiolaSoft Studio and for the past few years we have been working on an action adventure match 3 FPS called MATCHO. This year I also enrolled at FAMU Game Design.

title: Panel Discussion - current situation of the indie game industry in Czech Republic
abstract: Together with GDA CZ, Fuchs+Dachs game dev studio is organising a small one day EVENT that would be a part of this year’s Game Developers Session Conference, in Prague. We have one whole day specially organised for small teams, students and young game dev enthusiasts that we would like to greatly benefit from GDS 2025. The event is aimed for anyone interested in working in small teams, studying game design or small indie game dev teams and studios.

speakers.name: Lukáš Kolek
speakers.bio: Lukáš Kolek is the co-founder and CEO of Charles Games, the studio behind 10+ indie titles including the award-winning Playing Kafka, Svoboda 1945: Liberation and Beecarbonize, enjoyed by hundreds of thousands of players worldwide. Charles Games creates experiences that tackle serious themes, from historical trauma to the climate crisis.

Indie Play & Interviews
